Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Story: I was scrubbing the kitchen floor, rubber gloves pulled tight over my hands, when I heard my little brother’s laughter echo from the front yard. I glanced up just in time to see him darting toward the street, chasing after a runaway soccer ball. My heart leapt into my throat. As his older sibling, I knew I was supposed to keep him safe, to always be watching out for him. But my hands were covered in bleach and grime, and the safety protocols at work drilled into me: never touch your face, never remove gloves in the middle of a task, always wash hands before handling anything else. If I ran out now, I’d risk spreading chemicals everywhere, maybe even onto him. But if I hesitated, even for a second, he might step into traffic. The weight of both roles pressed down on me—my job’s rules versus my responsibility as a sister. My mind raced, torn between the urge to protect him and the fear of breaking the rules that kept us both safe in different ways.
